## ExecutionEngine interface implementation

### addArchive {#a35d30954df16f2628d44d0132737f996}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void MCJIT::addArchive (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/object/owningbinary">object::OwningBinary</a>&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/object/archive">object::Archive</a> &gt; A)</>}
  labels = {["virtual"]}>
addArchive - Add an Archive to the execution engine.

This method is only supported by <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcjit">MCJIT</a>. <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcjit">MCJIT</a> will use the archive to resolve external symbols in objects it is loading. If a symbol is found in the Archive the contained object file will be extracted (in memory) and loaded for possible execution.

### addObjectFile {#a63edbda22f0a1ab7ed361f27b5ff6145}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void MCJIT::addObjectFile (std::unique&#95;ptr&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/object/objectfile">object::ObjectFile</a> &gt; O)</>}
  labels = {["virtual"]}>
addObjectFile - Add an <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/objectfile">ObjectFile</a> to the execution engine.

This method is only supported by <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcjit">MCJIT</a>. <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcjit">MCJIT</a> will immediately load the object into memory and adds its symbols to the list used to resolve external symbols while preparing other objects for execution.

Objects added using this function will not be made executable until needed by another object.

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcjit">MCJIT</a> will take ownership of the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/objectfile">ObjectFile</a>.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/mcjit/mcjit-h/#l00208">208</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/mcjit/mcjit-h">MCJIT.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/mcjit/mcjit-cpp/#l00118">118</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/mcjit/mcjit-cpp">MCJIT.cpp</a>.

### finalizeObject {#a46de6cc1d24bff3fd2ae2006c8b35456}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="void MCJIT::finalizeObject ()"
  labels = {["virtual"]}>
finalizeObject - ensure the module is fully processed and is usable.

It is the user-level function for completing the process of making the object usable for execution. It should be called after sections within an object have been relocated using mapSectionAddress. When this method is called the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcjit">MCJIT</a> execution engine will reapply relocations for a loaded object. Is it OK to finalize a set of modules, add modules and finalize again.

### generateCodeForModule {#a5236c37b672e45c22ef2ebb47518871e}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void MCJIT::generateCodeForModule (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/module">Module</a> &#42; M)</>}
  labels = {["virtual"]}>
generateCodeForModule - Run code generation for the specified module and load it into memory.

When this function has completed, all code and data for the specified module, and any module on which this module depends, will be generated and loaded into memory, but relocations will not yet have been applied and all memory will be readable and writable but not executable.

This function is primarily useful when generating code for an external target, allowing the client an opportunity to remap section addresses before relocations are applied. Clients that intend to execute code locally can use the getFunctionAddress call, which will generate code and apply final preparations all in one step.

This method has no effect for the interpreter.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/mcjit/mcjit-h/#l00231">231</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/mcjit/mcjit-h">MCJIT.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/mcjit/mcjit-cpp/#l00188">188</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/mcjit/mcjit-cpp">MCJIT.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### getPointerToFunction {#ae9b6b618b65cd7355f31652c566c8e3c}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void &#42; MCJIT::getPointerToFunction (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/function">Function</a> &#42; F)</>}
  labels = {["virtual"]}>
getPointerToFunction - The different EE&#39;s represent function bodies in different ways.

They should each implement this to say what a function pointer should look like. When F is destroyed, the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/executionengine">ExecutionEngine</a> will remove its global mapping and free any machine code. Be sure no threads are running inside F when that happens.

This function is deprecated for the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcjit">MCJIT</a> execution engine. <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/use">Use</a> getFunctionAddress instead.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/mcjit/mcjit-h/#l00252">252</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/mcjit/mcjit-h">MCJIT.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/mcjit/mcjit-cpp/#l00410">410</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/mcjit/mcjit-cpp">MCJIT.cpp</a>.

### getPointerToNamedFunction {#a14f1cd53696dbd8b28129c519e8bd65d}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void &#42; MCJIT::getPointerToNamedFunction (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> Name, bool AbortOnFailure=<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/basicaliasanalysis-cpp/#af6d5cafbdfc5313e65d990120021a3ec">true</a>)</>}
  labels = {["virtual"]}>
getPointerToNamedFunction - This method returns the address of the specified function by using the dlsym function call.

As such it is only useful for resolving library symbols, not code generated symbols.

If AbortOnFailure is false and no function with the given name is found, this function silently returns a null pointer. Otherwise, it prints a message to stderr and aborts.

mapSectionAddress - map a section to its target address space value.

### runFunction {#a0198943262fb715d77dfd24ef32f9399}

<MemberDefinition

  labels = {["virtual"]}>
runFunction - Execute the specified function with the specified arguments, and return the result.

For <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcjit">MCJIT</a> execution engines, clients are encouraged to use the &quot;GetFunctionAddress&quot; method (rather than runFunction) and cast the returned uint64&#95;t to the desired function pointer type. However, for backwards compatibility <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcjit">MCJIT</a>&#39;s implementation can execute &#39;main-like&#39; function (i.e. those returning void or int, and taking either no arguments or (int, char&#42;&#91;&#93;)).

### setProcessAllSections {#a033df96c8b46bf1abba4a183718623c2}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="void llvm::MCJIT::setProcessAllSections (bool ProcessAllSections)"
  labels = {["inline", "virtual"]}>
setProcessAllSections (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcjit">MCJIT</a> Only): By default, only sections that are &quot;required for execution&quot; are passed to the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/rtdyldmemorymanager">RTDyldMemoryManager</a>, and other sections are discarded.

Passing &#39;true&#39; to this method will cause <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/runtimedyld">RuntimeDyld</a> to pass all sections to its <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/rtdyldmemorymanager">RTDyldMemoryManager</a> regardless of whether they are &quot;required to execute&quot; in the usual sense.

Rationale: Some <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcjit">MCJIT</a> clients want to be able to inspect metadata sections (e.g. Dwarf, Stack-maps) to enable functionality or analyze performance. Passing these sections to the memory manager allows the client to make policy about the relevant sections, rather than having <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcjit">MCJIT</a> do it.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/mcjit/mcjit-h/#l00227">227</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/mcjit/mcjit-h">MCJIT.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### emitObject {#a6ba8a53658ba2413897f0b674d06faec}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>std::unique&#95;ptr&lt; MemoryBuffer &gt; MCJIT::emitObject (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/module">Module</a> &#42; M)</>}
  labels = {["protected"]}>
emitObject – Generate a JITed object in memory from the specified module Currently, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcjit">MCJIT</a> only supports a single module and the module passed to this function call is expected to be the contained module.

The module is passed as a parameter here to prepare for multiple module support in the future.
